According to one survey published in 1997, looking at more than one hundred thousand students, adolescents who had experienced either physical or sexual abuse were two to four times as likely to be using drugs as those who reported no such molestation.[8] The ones who suffered both physical and sexual abuse were at least twice as likely to be using drugs as others who had been subjected to either abuse by itself. Alcohol consumption has shown a similar pattern: in a national sample of ten thousand adolescents, those with histories of sexual abuse were three times more likely to begin drinking in adolescence.[9]&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; Now that we have cleared away the thicket of mistaken beliefs about addiction, gotten a sense of what it does for people under its sway, and begun to consider what sorts of life experiences would make those ‚Äúperks‚Äù so palpable and attractive, I propose to pull back the curtain even further in the next chapter. It is yet another myth‚Äîat once convenient and highly damaging‚Äîthat in our world there is a category we can label ‚Äúaddicts,‚Äù designating some identifiable group of poor, unfortunate souls, and then, neatly segregated from ‚Äúthose people,‚Äù there are the rest of us ‚Äúnormal‚Äù folks.&#13; To twist a line from the great George Carlin, it‚Äôs a big club‚Äîand we‚Äôre all in it.&#13; &#13;

 &#13; Chapter 16&#13; Show of Hands: A New View of Addiction&#13; &#13; We are long overdue for a new perspective‚Äîboth because our understanding of the neuroscience underlying addiction has changed and because so many existing treatments simply don‚Äôt work.&#13; ‚ÄîMaia Szalavitz[*]&#13; &#13; Having delineated what addiction is and isn‚Äôt, and recognizing its impetus and function in people‚Äôs lives, I‚Äôd like to offer a new working definition, one I believe is truer and more powerful than its antecedents. In eschewing genetic determinism, it entails the possibility of healing. I should issue a caution, though. While more precise and more hopeful, my definition is also more ecumenical‚Äîit makes addiction‚Äôs ‚Äúbig tent‚Äù even bigger. You might just find yourself under it.&#13; &#13; Addiction is a complex psychological, emotional, physiological, neurobiological, social, and spiritual process. It manifests through any behavior in which a person finds temporary relief or pleasure and therefore craves, but that in the long term causes them or others negative consequences, and yet the person refuses or is unable to give it up. Accordingly, the three main hallmarks of addiction are&#13; &#13; &#13; &#13; short-term relief or pleasure and therefore craving;&#13; &#13; &#13; long-term suffering for oneself or others; and&#13; &#13; &#13; an inability to stop.&#13; &#13; &#13; Two things to note right away: First, my definition omits disease‚Äîwhich is not to say that it must exclude it. As I articulated in chapter 6, most illnesses are best understood as complex processes manifesting a person‚Äôs entire life, rather than discrete ‚Äúthings‚Äù in themselves. In the end, as with many conditions, calling addiction a disease may capture relevant aspects of it without coming close to explaining the phenomenon, let alone granting us a workable pathway to healing it at its source.&#13; Second, this definition is not restricted to drugs. The same drive that often devotes itself to substances can activate any number of behaviors, from compulsive sexual roving to pornography; from inveterate shopping to the internet (both of which habits I know well); from gaming to gambling; from any sort of binge eating or drinking to purging; from work to extreme sports; from relentless exercising to compulsive relationship-seeking; from psychedelics to meditation. The issue is never the external target but one‚Äôs internal relationship to it. Are you craving and partaking of something that affords you temporary relief or pleasure, inviting or incurring negative consequences but not giving it up? Welcome to the meeting. Free coffee in the back.&#13; If you‚Äôve seen me speak on this topic, whether in person or on YouTube, you‚Äôll probably know what I‚Äôm about to ask next. I usually pause here to invite a show of hands: ‚ÄúWho, by the definition just given, is now or ever has been addicted?‚Äù No matter the audience size, virtually no one‚Äôs hand ever stays lowered‚Äîexcept, I like to jest, for the occasional liar‚Äôs. That is how downright normal addictions are in our culture today. I invite you, fearless reader, to put yourself to the same test, with or without the hand-raising.&#13; Of course, not all addictions are created equal, except in the broadest of broad strokes. My HIV- and hepatitis-C-ridden patients in the Downtown Eastside surely stand apart from most of us in the degrees of suffering that hurled them into their habits, in the extent to which their dependencies dominate their lives, and, too, in the dire consequences their habits visit upon them. This is to say nothing about the diminished inner or outer resources available to them, often for socioeconomic and racialized reasons not of their creation. They differ also in the degrees of ostracization and punishment society has inflicted and continues to inflict on them.&#13; These acute differences of degree do matter, and we should not flatten or erase them. But they do not change the fact that the addiction process has certain intrinsic features known to all who live it. It spares no one, not even people at the top. That includes those whose destructive habits, in our culture‚Äôs topsy-turvy value system, are spun as ‚Äúsuccess.‚Äù Nor do these differences obviate the fact that most of us ‚Äúnormal‚Äù citizens bear far more resemblance than we‚Äôd be inclined to admit with those we deride or pity for their more severe or glaring dependencies. It‚Äôs not even a fine line that separates ‚Äúus,‚Äù the upstanding, from ‚Äúthem,‚Äù the downtrodden: it‚Äôs a made-up one.&#13; Here it helps to remember the severity spectrum when it comes to trauma. All kinds of suffering, from the less obvious developmental wounds we have called small-t to the more overt big-T traumas, can cry out for addictive pain relief. Again, trauma/injury is about what happens inside us, and how those effects persist, not what happens to us. An inquiry into ‚ÄúWhy the pain?‚Äù has to leave space for the kinds of emotional injuries that may elude conscious recall or, much more often, seem unremarkable to the person doing the remembering.&#13; It is not uncommon for people to tell themselves they enjoyed a ‚Äúhappy childhood.‚Äù As long as life is going reasonably well, we may lack any reason to question this narrative. When addiction is present in oneself or a loved one, some inquiry is definitely in order.[*] Looking inward with compassion, most people will be able to locate themselves somewhere on the trauma/psychological-injury spectrum. Genuine happy memories do not rule out emotional suffering, but the usual bias is to recall the former and to suppress awareness of the latter. It has been my experience that even people with the most insistent ‚Äúhappy childhood‚Äù narrative will, if asked the right questions, very quickly come to realize that their autobiography has been riddled with blind spots.&#13; In 2015, the writer and theater artist Stephanie Wittels Wachs lost her younger brother, Harris, to an overdose. She herself is a self-acknowledged workaholic, to the detriment of her family life. Until she invited me onto her Last Day podcast, she was convinced‚Äîadamant, in fact‚Äîthat she and Harris had grown up in a normal, happy home. Her remembered evidence for that normalcy and happiness included their mother‚Äôs involvement in many school activities‚Äîfield trip chaperone, president of the PTA, and so on‚Äîand a home life where the spousal roles were stable in the traditional sense: working dad, housewife mom. The sense of security inspired by all these arrangements may well have been real; it certainly sounds like Wittels Wachs grew up with a mother and father who loved their children as best they could and provided for their physical and social needs. Yet embedded in that ‚Äúnormalcy‚Äù were experiences of profound emotional hurt she had completely discounted, until they were conjured up from the depths by my questions. ‚ÄúThis whole exchange caught me off guard,‚Äù she confessed to her listeners afterward. ‚ÄúHe is absolutely fucking correct. My talking points on my happy childhood are incomplete.‚Äù&#13; David Sheff was likewise ‚Äúcaught off guard‚Äù by a similar realization. His book, Beautiful Boy: A Father‚Äôs Journey Through His Son‚Äôs Addiction, which depicts his son Nick‚Äôs nearly fatal stimulant habit, was a bestseller and, more recently, the subject of a poignant film starring Steve Carell and Timoth√©e Chalamet. There had been no big-T trauma in this family, no child abuse or dire adversity. Perplexed, Sheff was forced to ask himself uncomfortable questions to understand what had impelled his talented, vivacious, highly sensitive eldest child into a life-threatening addiction. Looking back, Sheff saw that Nick‚Äôs pain must have originated early on, in the crucible of a dysfunctional parental relationship. ‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt have been together,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúWe had terrible, terrible problems in our marriage.‚Äù Self-delusion played a major role: even while engaging in an extramarital affair with a family friend, Sheff harbored ‚Äúthis fantasy in my mind that, you know, if I was happy and she was happy, the kids would be together and then we‚Äôd have this happy family and we‚Äôd be sort of freeing them from these two traumatic families . . . I actually believed that I was doing this in some ways for Nick. I was justifying it, trying to make it okay.‚Äù It is to Sheff‚Äôs credit that he has been willing to look back with open eyes at how it actually was. I don‚Äôt know the details, but Sheff did say that he and his son are now having candid and mutually compassionate conversations about those days, with the shared understanding that the pain of Nick‚Äôs childhood was a major driver of his later difficulties.&#13; As I have, Dr. Dan Sumrok has met the occasional trauma skeptic. With a long, graying beard hanging mid-chest and a passionate oratory style, this friend and colleague of mine in addiction medicine seems the very vision of a biblical prophet. But if Dan is an evangelist for anything, it‚Äôs sanity. Over his career as a family physician, first at the University of Tennessee medical school in Memphis, then in Nashville, and more recently in a rural area, he has treated nearly twenty-five thousand people with opiate addiction. He, too, sees past the medical view of addiction as disease, genetic or otherwise; in his experience, too, trauma is the foundational factor. ‚ÄúI began writing about this in 1980 when I was just discharged from the military. I was a first-year medical student, and my life was flying apart. I would say my best friends were George, Jack, and Jim‚Äîthe whiskey brothers.‚Äù[*] ‚ÄúSome people,‚Äù Dan relates, ‚Äúthe real militant Twelve-Steppers, will say to me, and some of the treatment programs have said, ‚ÄòYou know, it‚Äôs not all about trauma, Dr. Sumrok.‚Äô I do want to reassure them, so I say, ‚ÄòI promise you, I‚Äôm keeping an open mind. I‚Äôm waiting to see the first person for whom it‚Äôs not all about trauma.‚Äô‚Äù One would have to wait a long time.&#13; Whatever the degree of injury, all addiction is a kind of refugee story: from intolerable feelings incurred through adversity and never processed, and into a state of temporary freedom, even if illusory. Again, try saying no to that.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; It may surprise many to learn that no drug is in itself addictive, not even the most notorious ‚Äúhigh risk‚Äù ones like crack or methamphetamine. Most people who try drugs, any drug, even repeatedly, never become addicted. The reasons why throw further light on the nature of addiction.&#13; I often ask audiences, ‚ÄúIs alcohol addictive: yes or no? Is food addictive: yes or no? Or work: yes or no? Or sex: yes or no? Or pornography, or shopping: yes or no?‚Äù The right answer, embedded in the question, is ‚Äúyes or no,‚Äù depending on the degree of pain one needs to soothe.&#13; San Diego internal medicine specialist Dr. Vincent Felitti was one of the lead investigators of the now famous (though not famous enough) Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) Study. The study emerged after Felitti decided to listen to the life histories of patients at an obesity clinic who all reported childhood traumas. Carried out in the 1990s in California‚Äôs Kaiser Permanente health care network, the research showed that among a cohort of over seventeen thousand mostly Caucasian, middle-class persons, the more adversity a child had been exposed to, the greater the risk of addictions, mental health issues, and other medical problems they faced in adulthood.[1] Adversity was categorized under three general headings: abuse (psychological, physical, sexual); neglect (physical, emotional); household dysfunction (alcoholism or drug use in the home, divorce or loss of a biological parent, depression or mental illness in the home, mother treated violently, imprisoned household member). The impacts of such experiences did not merely add up; they multiplied each other. An adult reporting an ACE score of 6 had a risk of intravenous drug use forty-six-fold greater than a child with none of the adversities named.&#13; ‚ÄúIt is commonly believed,‚Äù Felitti said, discussing his research, ‚Äúthat repeated use of many street drugs will in itself produce addiction. Our findings challenge those views . . . Addiction has relatively little to do with the supposed addictive properties of certain substances, other than their all providing a desirable psychoactive relief . . . In other words, this is an understandable attempt at self-treatment with something that almost works, thus creating a drive for further doses.‚Äù[2]&#13; Felitti‚Äôs childhood adversity findings lay further waste to the myth of genetic determinism that I began debunking in the chapter on epigenetics. No single addiction gene has ever been found‚Äînor ever will be. There may exist some collection of genes that predisposes people to susceptibility, but a predisposition is not the same as a predetermination. What‚Äôs true of physical illness is just as true of addiction: genes are turned on and off by the environment, and we now know that early adversity affects genetic activity in ways that create a template for future dysfunction. Human and animal studies have both confirmed that any genetic risks for substance abuse can be offset by being reared in a nurturing environment.[3]&#13; One of the happiest email acknowledgments I ever received was from the grateful mother of a four-year-old. Her husband, a former alcoholic, refused to have children, so afraid had he been of passing the ‚Äúalcoholism gene‚Äù to his offspring. Having read my book on addiction, he recognized the traumatic sources of his alcohol habit and gave up his fear of this nonexistent gene. And just in time‚Äîhis wife had been nearly past the child-bearing age. I couldn‚Äôt suppress a self-satisfied chortle. I‚Äôd been thanked before for ‚Äúsaving‚Äù the lives of people I had never met, but never for having been the cause of one at long distance.&#13; The way childhood adversity engenders the neurobiology of addiction has to do with the interpersonal-biological science we have already examined. Experiences of stress in the womb can predispose to addiction, for example, by altering the brain‚Äôs ability to respond to stress in functional ways. They can also have long-term influence on the parts of the brain that modulate the incentive-motivation system impaired in all addictions, whether to drugs or behaviors.[*] As the psychiatric practitioner, neuroscientist, author, and leading trauma researcher Dr. Bruce Perry told me, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done work, and a lot of other people have done work, showing that essentially the number and density of dopamine receptors in these [brain] areas is determined in utero.‚Äù[4]&#13; Whoever coined the slang term ‚Äúdope‚Äù for drugs was onto something, because all addictions, whether to drugs or behaviors, involve dopamine. Dopamine is the essential neurotransmitter in the motivation system, without which all mammals are inert, inactive, and lacking all incentive. A hungry laboratory mouse whose brain is artificially denuded of its dopamine apparatus will starve himself while standing in front of a plate of food. In fact, every addict is a dopamine fiend, outsourcing the hunt for the homegrown chemical hit that makes the present moment exciting and vibrant. For virtually every ‚Äúpositive‚Äù feeling or quality people derive from their substances or behavior of choice, there are endogenous‚Äînaturally occurring‚Äîbrain chemicals implicated. Addiction begins as an attempt to induce feelings that we were biologically programmed to generate innately, and would have‚Äîif unhealthy development hadn‚Äôt got in the way.&#13; Sex addiction, for example, has nothing to do with a ‚Äúhigh sex drive‚Äù and everything to do with dopamine. New York social worker and former Fordham and Rutgers Universities adjunct professor Zachary Alti specializes in sex therapy and behavioral addictions, particularly addiction to porn. ‚ÄúStudies are suggesting,‚Äù he told me, ‚Äúthat when viewing a pornographic image, we get a dopamine spike in our brain. When viewing images after images, we get spike after spike after spike. Whereas with substance addictions you typically get one or a few spikes just before use, with behavioral addictions dopamine itself is the substance, the primary component. Especially in pornography addiction, these dopamine spikes happen over and over and over again.‚Äù As with smartphone and app companies, pornographers are well aware that their profits rest on the hijacking of their consumers‚Äô brains. The sociologist Gail Dines, author of the bracing 2010 book Pornland: How Porn Has Hijacked Our Sexuality, reports on an article in the trade publication Adult Video News, in which an industry insider trumpets a Stanford University study on cyber-sex addiction showing that 20 percent of porn users are hooked. ‚ÄúIn a true capitalist approach,‚Äù she notes, the article is cheerfully headed ‚ÄúExploiting the Data.‚Äù[5]&#13; What about the feelings of love that people find in addictions, particularly with opiates‚Äîthe warmth Jamie Lee Curtis and others spoke of? That is, in large part, a function of the brain‚Äôs internal opiate apparatus in which endorphins, our own natural, endogenous opiates, are the neurotransmitters. Dr. Jaak Panksepp suggested twenty years ago that opiate addiction is rooted in the evolutionary brain mechanisms that promote social bonding: nurturing, emotional closeness, and social affiliation. ‚ÄúWe would anticipate,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúthat individuals who experience especially intense social distress and insecurities would be especially vulnerable to opiate abuse, and this prediction has been affirmed by some clinical research. Indeed, the same dynamic may help explain why opiate addictions are especially prevalent among the socially disenfranchised.‚Äù[6] The current opioid overdose crisis in the United States, and to lesser degrees in Canada and the U.K., has tragically borne out the acuity of this observation.&#13; The endorphin system, too, is dependent on supportive, attuned relationships early in life for its development. ‚ÄúFace-to-face interactions activate the child‚Äôs sympathetic nervous system,‚Äù writes Louis Cozolino, a clinical psychologist, neuroscientist, and professor of psychology at Pepperdine University. ‚ÄúThese higher levels of activation correlate with increased production of oxytocin, prolactin, endorphins, and dopamine; some of the same biochemical systems involved in addiction.‚Äù[7] A child‚Äôs closeness with the attuned, emotionally available parent promotes the optimal growth of brain systems; the lack of it inhibits healthy development.&#13; Work has been the main, but not only, addiction of singer-songwriter Alanis Morissette. In endorphin-friendly terms, she now speaks of it as a compensation. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an attachment-craving in being famous,‚Äù she said when we spoke. ‚ÄúIf you think about it, eyeballs are on you. Everyone‚Äôs hyper-responsive. Everyone‚Äôs paying attention to you . . . You keep chasing that sense of being loved and adored and stared at.‚Äù Morissette was seeking to attain through her fame that state of infant bliss so many miss out on or experience all too briefly.&#13; When Robert Palmer sang about being addicted to love, he might have been speaking to all of us with our hands raised‚Äîall the drug addicts, all the workaholics, all the compulsive gamblers and shoppers and eaters, all those hopelessly chasing the next exciting high or soothing low. Except it‚Äôs not really love we get hooked on but our desperate attempts to cope with its lack, by any means necessary.&#13; Sobering stuff, I know. But we might as well face it.&#13; &#13;

 &#13; Chapter 17&#13; An Inaccurate Map of Our Pain: What We Get Wrong About Mental Illness&#13; &#13; We don‚Äôt understand any major mental disorder biologically.&#13; ‚ÄîProfessor Anne Harrington[*]&#13; &#13; At age nineteen, a freshman journalism student at the University of Florida, Darrell Hammond was plunged into his first experience of searing mental distress. ‚ÄúI was in unspeakable terror,‚Äù the comedian recalled. ‚ÄúThat level of fear‚ÄîI don‚Äôt even know how I survived it. The doctors were treating me for depression and paranoia, and for psychosis because I told them that I had seen someone talking, and the words didn‚Äôt come out at the same time their mouth was moving.‚Äù He was prescribed an antidepressant, amitriptyline, as well as the antipsychotic thioridazine. Over the subsequent decades, Hammond estimated that he was evaluated by up to forty psychiatrists and labeled with multiple diagnoses, including depression, bipolar disorder, and complex PTSD, and he didn‚Äôt recall what else. The assumption that guided his treatment was the same one that dominates much of medical thinking: that such torments are caused by a biological disease of the brain. Accordingly, he was treated with an ever-changing cocktail of medications. Throughout years of professional success, including an unprecedented fourteen-year run on Saturday Night Live‚Äîhis range expressed in roles from Bill Clinton to, perhaps most belovedly, a jocularly vulgar Sean Connery‚Äîhe continued to feel lost, irritable, isolated, and despondent. The only recourses he could find to interrupt his misery were self-medicating with alcohol and overt self-harm: his body still bears the scars of over fifty self-inflicted cuts.&#13; Thirty-five years into his psychiatric odyssey, Hammond met a clinician, Dr. Nabil Kotbi at New York City‚Äôs Weill Cornell Medical College, who changed his life with two short sentences: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want you to call what you have a mental illness. You have been injured.‚Äù The insight that his symptoms were not the manifestations of some mysterious medical condition, Hammond told me, ‚Äúwas a ‚ÄòHallelujah Chorus‚Äô moment . . . What [Dr. Kotbi] seemed to be saying to me was that mental illness comes from somewhere very specific. It has a story, and in that story, you‚Äôre the only one that has no power.‚Äù In the decades between his first encounter with the mental health system and his meeting this particular psychiatrist, no one had asked Hammond about traumatic childhood experiences. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt describe what it was like to go into a doctor‚Äôs office, in acute pain, and have them look at me and go, ‚ÄòYou shouldn‚Äôt be feeling this way.‚Äô No one at the time was saying, ‚ÄòHey, you‚Äôre probably a victim of child abuse.‚Äô At that time, if you felt bad for no apparent reason, they called you bipolar. That‚Äôs all they knew. ‚ÄòHe has unexplainable highs and lows,‚Äô you know. They treated me with [the mood stabilizers] lithium and then Depakote. Neither of those were successful. Nothing was really successful until the truth about my life was acknowledged.‚Äù The truth of Hammond‚Äôs life included a cavalcade of abuse at the hands of his mother.[*]&#13; While mental ailments certainly exhibit some features of illness‚Äîthe brain seeming to function like a disordered organ‚Äîmainstream psychiatry takes the biological emphasis too far, reducing everything mostly to an imbalance of DNA-dictated brain chemicals. Psychiatrist Kay Redfield Jamison, one of today‚Äôs most eloquent authors on manic-depressive illness, also known as bipolar disorder, wrote the memoir Unquiet Mind. This book is essential reading for anyone wanting to appreciate the experience of an exquisite consciousness oscillating from episodes of hyper-elation to immobilizing despair. And yet, embedded in Dr. Jamison‚Äôs gorgeously rendered recollections are faulty assumptions that exemplify the simplistic genetic narrative to which psychiatry still clings. Here she recalls a manic episode: ‚ÄúMy mind was flying high that day, courtesy of whatever witches‚Äô brew of neurotransmitters God had programmed into my genes.‚Äù In truth, neither God nor genes have much to do with it.&#13; In her Touched with Fire, an equally poignant book, Jamison puts it more explicitly, asserting that ‚Äúthe genetic basis for manic-depressive illness is especially compelling, indeed almost incontrovertible.‚Äù[1] Twenty-five years on, we know that the hard, scientific evidence is not only not compelling; it is nearly nonexistent. The ‚Äúalmost incontrovertible‚Äù proof Dr. Jamison relied on is the literature on family histories, adoption, and twin studies, all of which are riddled with false assumptions.[*] The proof she alludes to for genetic causes is only ‚Äúcompelling‚Äù if one is already a believer: on the evidence itself, it is pure science fiction.[2] It is also inelegant: in my work with mental distress and addictions‚Äîincluding my own‚ÄîI‚Äôve always found more than enough in people‚Äôs personal histories to account for their psychic suffering, without superimposing a narrative dominated by genetic predetermination.&#13; The term ‚Äúmental illness,‚Äù even as it describes real phenomena, focuses our attention centrally on brain physiology, analogous to how, say, anginal pain connotes a restriction of oxygen supply to the heart muscle, owing to narrowed cardiac arteries. It also implies that the problem necessarily falls within the domain of medicine. Despite whatever partial truths they contain, these assumptions are highly questionable and limit our understanding. Worse, they generate harm, both in the sense that they leave many people subjected to inappropriate treatments and in that they displace perspectives that could be far more complete, humane, and helpful. The biological determinism that governed Darrell Hammond‚Äôs physicians also placed his condition beyond his own agency to heal, thereby reinforcing the ‚ÄúYou are the only one that has no power‚Äù story he spoke of. Such a view threatens to keep the sufferer largely in the position of passively receiving treatment, his symptoms ameliorated by medications to be ingested, in many cases, for a lifetime.&#13; In its predominantly biological approach, psychiatry commits the same error as other medical specialties: it takes complex processes intricately bound with life experience and emotional development, slaps the ‚Äúdisease‚Äù label on them, and calls it a day.&#13; Little in the training of doctors prepares them to wonder about their patients‚Äô lived experience, much less to seek the sources of their malaises therein. Simplistic explanations, which require little time or emotional energy, are an attractive fallback position. Many doctors are intensely uncomfortable facing their own hidden sorrows and wounds‚Äîwhat Carl Jung called our shadow side. And not only doctors: as a well-known colleague told me, ‚ÄúPatients play into this as well. They don‚Äôt want to look at their lives, either. It would involve getting into recovery, changing something. It‚Äôs enormous work to recover from our childhoods. It‚Äôs incredibly worthwhile, but it‚Äôs a lot of work.‚Äù The gospel of genetic causation shields us from having to confront our hurts, leaving us all the more at their mercy.&#13; If anything, this limitation is especially calamitous in the realm of mental suffering, and even less justified. After all, unlike in cancer or rheumatoid arthritis, no physical findings, blood tests, biopsies, radiographs, or scans can either support or rule out psychiatric diagnoses. That statement may surprise many readers, so it bears repeating. There are no measurable physical markers of mental illness other than the subjective (a person‚Äôs description of their own mood, say) and the behavioral (sleep patterns, appetite, etc.).&#13; Like all concepts, mental illness is a construct‚Äîa particular frame we have developed to understand a phenomenon and explain what we observe. It may be valid in some respects and erroneous in others; it most definitely isn‚Äôt objective. Unchecked, it becomes an all-encompassing lens through which we perceive and interpret. Such a way of seeing can say as much about the biases and values of the culture that gives rise to it as about the phenomenon being seen, whether a religious concept like ‚Äúsinful‚Äù or a biomedical one like ‚Äúmentally ill.‚Äù[3] In some cultures, for example, people with visions may become prophets or shamans. In ours, most likely they would be deemed insane. One wonders how a Joan of Arc or the medieval saint and composer of sacred music Hildegard of Bingen would fare at the hands of the contemporary mental health system. I once speculated out loud, in front of an audience of hundreds, what would happen if I strode up to the prime minister of Canada and pronounced, Joan-like, that I have seen the future in which he leads the global fight against climate change, beginning with giving up his reliance on campaign funding from the fossil fuel industry.&#13; Other than modern culture‚Äôs typical, left-brain materialist bent, how did we arrive at this view of mental illness as an essentially biologically rooted phenomenon? In part, it seems to be a holdover from a once tantalizing aspiration in medical science, a mission unaccomplished. ‚ÄúPsychiatry today stands on the threshold of becoming an exact science, as precise and quantifiable as molecular genetics,‚Äù wrote the journalist Jon Franklin in a Pulitzer Prize‚Äìwinning series in 1984.[4] As with the ultimately unfulfilled promise of the genomic revolution to explain health and illness, the initial enthusiasm for the prospect of a science-based psychiatry was virtually unbounded. Nearly forty years later we are no closer to crossing this imagined threshold; if anything, we are further away. When the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) was published by the American Psychiatric Association in 2013, Dr. David Kupfer, head of the task force responsible for it, acknowledged as much. ‚ÄúIn the future,‚Äù he stated in a press release, ‚Äúwe hope to be able to identify disorders using biological and genetic markers that provide precise diagnoses that can be delivered with complete reliability and validity. Yet this promise, which we have anticipated since the 1970s, remains disappointingly distant. We‚Äôve been telling patients for several decades that we are waiting for biomarkers. We‚Äôre still waiting.‚Äù[5]&#13; The journalist and author Robert Whitaker, formerly the director of publications for Harvard Medical School, was a firm believer in the chemical-imbalance theory of mental illness‚Äîuntil he wasn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúWhen I first started writing about psychiatry, I believed that to be true,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúI mean, why wouldn‚Äôt I?‚Äù His disillusionment arose from research he uncovered while reporting for the Boston Globe. ‚ÄúI said to people, ‚ÄòCan you just tell me where you found that depression is due to serotonin or where you actually found that schizophrenia is due to too much dopamine?‚Äô I asked to read the source materials and, I swear to God, they said, ‚ÄòWell, we didn‚Äôt really find that. It‚Äôs a metaphor.‚Äô The most amazing thing was, when you trace it in their own research, you find they didn‚Äôt find it! The divergence from what you‚Äôre being told from what is in their own scientific literature‚Äîthat‚Äôs the key‚Äîit was just stunning to me.‚Äù These conspicuous non-findings are documented in Whitaker‚Äôs book Anatomy of an Epidemic and have been corroborated in other literature.[6]&#13; Contrary to what I, too, used to believe, a diagnosis like ADHD or depression or bipolar illness explains nothing. No diagnosis ever does. Diagnoses are abstractions, or summaries: sometimes helpful, always incomplete. They are professional shorthand for describing constellations of symptoms a person may report, or of other people‚Äôs observations of someone‚Äôs behavior patterns, thoughts, and emotions. For the individual in question, a diagnosis may seem to account for and validate a lifetime of experiences previously too diffuse or nebulous to put one‚Äôs finger on. That can be a first and positive step toward healing. I know this from firsthand experience.&#13; The dead end comes when we assume or believe that the diagnosis equals an explanation‚Äîan especially futile view when it comes to illnesses of something as inherently abstract as the mind. As the British psychologist Lucy Johnstone said to me, ‚ÄúIn physical illness you have, in principle, a way of checking it out. You can say, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs look at the blood test or the enzyme levels.‚Äô And you could, in most cases, confirm or disconfirm it. But in psychiatry, it‚Äôs simply a circular argument, isn‚Äôt it? Why does this person have mood swings? Because they have bipolar disorder. How do you know they have bipolar disorder? Because they have mood swings.‚Äù My mind goes to A. A. Milne‚Äôs Pooh and Piglet walking in the snow in an unwitting circle, shuddering as they come across yet more ‚ÄúHeffalump‚Äù tracks at every turn.&#13; An oft-heard objection to mental health diagnoses, particularly with regard to children, is that they ‚Äúpathologize‚Äù or ‚Äústigmatize‚Äù ordinary, healthy feelings or behaviors. Aren‚Äôt kids supposed to get bored or antsy, angry or sad? My answer would be yes‚Äîand it‚Äôs not that simple. While overdiagnosis is certainly a risk, I don‚Äôt see the spike in, say, ADHD cases over the past decades as being due solely to gullible parents, hapless teachers, overzealous school shrinks, and unscrupulous drug companies. As I discussed in earlier chapters, the world into which kids are being born these days might as well have been designed to promote disruptions of cognitive function and emotional self-regulation. Everything I have seen tells me we are witnessing a sea change in children‚Äôs mental well-being.&#13; Why, then, do I persist in my critique of the diagnostic model? Because diagnoses reveal nothing about the underlying events and dynamics that animate the perceptions and experiences in question. They keep our gaze trained on effects and not their myriad causes. There could be multiple reasons why a child may have trouble paying attention or be restless, disengaged, and fidgety: anxiety, stresses at home, boredom with material she finds uninteresting, resistance to the constraints of sitting in a classroom, fear of bullying, an authoritarian teacher, trauma‚Äîeven birth month, believe it or not. A University of British Columbia study looked at the prescription records of almost one million B.C. schoolchildren over an eleven-year period and found that kids born in December were 39 percent more likely to be diagnosed with ADHD than classmates born the previous January. The reason? December kids entered the same grade nearly a year younger than their January counterparts‚Äîthey were eleven months behind in brain development. They were being medicated not for a ‚Äúgenetic brain disorder‚Äù but for naturally delayed maturation of the brain circuits of attention and self-regulation.[7]&#13; Or consider the DSM-5 diagnosis of oppositional defiant disorder (ODD), often tacked on to ADHD and other ‚Äúdiseases.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf your child or teenager has a frequent and persistent pattern of anger, irritability, arguing, defiance or vindictiveness toward you and other authority figures, he or she may have oppositional defiant disorder,‚Äù advises the Mayo Clinic.[8] The clue is in the word ‚Äútoward‚Äù: oppositionality, by definition, can arise only in the context of a relationship. I can suffer symptoms of a cold in isolation, or break my ankle on my own. I cannot oppose anyone or be angry or irritable with anyone unless that ‚Äúanyone‚Äù is in some relationship with me. ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt believe me,‚Äù I sometimes tell audiences of therapists, parents, teachers, or medical professionals, ‚Äújust lock yourself in your room tonight, make sure you are absolutely alone, and oppose somebody. If you succeed, put it on YouTube‚Äîit‚Äôll go viral in no time.‚Äù&#13; Given that a child develops in the context of relationships, her behavior will be intelligible to us only if we look at the relational environment. Seen this way, these so-called ODD kids turn out to be ones who lack sufficient connection with nurturing adults and have a natural resistance to being controlled by people they do not fully trust or feel close enough to. This aversion, furthermore, is only magnified by all attempts to shame or cajole it into submission. To call this ‚Äúdisordered‚Äù says nothing about the child‚Äôs inner experience; it reflects only the perspective of the ones who find his recalcitrance inconvenient. It is also completely obtuse about how emotional power dynamics work: there is nothing disordered in resisting authority figures that, for whatever reason, we do not feel confident in and safe with.&#13; If we are today seeing more youngsters in automatic resistance mode, the question we must return to is, How does this culture disrupt healthy adult-child relationships? Why are we diagnosing children with a disorder, instead of ‚Äúdiagnosing‚Äù‚Äîand treating‚Äîtheir families, communities, schools, and society?&#13; The psychiatrist, author, and leading trauma researcher Bruce Perry[*] has come to disdain diagnoses almost completely. This is no knee-jerk prejudice: his dim view of the norms and practices of his field follows decades spent assessing tens of thousands of troubled children, and extensive contributions to the vast literature on adversity and what we define as ‚Äúdisorders.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhen I got into psychiatry,‚Äù Dr. Perry told me, ‚Äúit became clear really quickly that the diagnoses were not connected to the physiology, that they were just descriptive, and that there were hundreds of physiological routes to somebody having an attention problem, for example. And yet the profession acted as if these descriptive labels were really a thing . . . I knew that if we were doing ‚Äòresearch,‚Äô if we were using these hollow descriptors which we call ‚Äòdiagnoses‚Äô and then study interventions and outcomes, we would just get garbage. And that‚Äôs what we‚Äôve done.‚Äù&#13; These days Dr. Perry is adamant that ‚Äúeven playing the DSM game is completely wrong.‚Äù When invited to contribute to one of the manual‚Äôs editions, he refused. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòListen, in twenty-five years they are going to look back and won‚Äôt believe that we thought about people that way.‚Äô It‚Äôs not a valid way to think about the complexities of human beings.‚Äù He practices what he preaches in the clinic he helps run. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt used diagnoses for fifteen, twenty years,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand it really has not interfered with our ability to do good clinical work. In fact, we‚Äôre able to do better clinical work without using those labels.‚Äù&#13; Based on my observations in family practice and my understanding of human development, I have followed the same lines. When I work with any mental health condition, say depression or anxiety or ADHD or addiction, I‚Äôm not so interested in the formal diagnosis as such. My ‚Äúdiagnostic‚Äù focus goes to the specific challenges the person is facing in their life and the traumas animating those challenges. As for ‚Äúprescriptions,‚Äù I am primarily interested in what will promote the healing of the psychic wounds the ongoing traumatic patterns represent.&#13; Now, here‚Äôs a perhaps surprising assertion: I‚Äôm not anti-pharmacology. No one who‚Äôs felt or witnessed the beneficial effects of psychiatric drugs can deny that neurobiology must, indeed, play a role in the dynamics and potential easing of mental distress, just as it does in all our experiences. Sometimes the healing of which I just spoke can be helped along‚Äînot made to happen, certainly, but assisted‚Äîby the intelligent use of these medications. That is not just my professional opinion but my personal experience as well.&#13; In my mid-forties, I decided to go on the serotonin-enhancing drug Prozac. (Among the brain‚Äôs principal neurotransmitters, or chemical messengers, serotonin is believed to be active in such functions as mood regulation and the dampening of aggression.) The skepticism I harbored about this growing trend to medicate millions was eclipsed by my hunger for respite from the daily severities of my state of mind, as summed up grimly in a diary entry from that time: ‚ÄúI have no energy for life. I have spent every weekend for the past two months‚Äîevery free weekend‚Äîin an enervated, passive, demoralized state, depressed and depressing to be with.‚Äù&#13; I was soon a different person. Within days, my wife noted with relief the softening of my facial features. I now greeted mornings with vim instead of venom, lost my irritability around my family, smiled and laughed a lot more, and could feel and express tenderness where before I‚Äôd been cold and brittle. It was as if someone had bandaged my aching heart so that it no longer hurt or bruised at the slightest touch. I found myself marveling to my sister-in-law: ‚ÄúYou mean people can feel like this normally? I had no idea!‚Äù My experience was similar to what, some years later, the writer Elizabeth Wurtzel would depict in her 1994 personal account Prozac Nation. ‚ÄúOne morning I woke up and really did want to live,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúIt was as if the miasma of depression had lifted off me, in the same way that the fog in San Francisco rises as the day wears on. Was it the Prozac? No doubt.‚Äù&#13; As happens with many new converts, my initial reticence quickly gave way to a period of outsize enthusiasm. In my medical practice I became something of a Prozac booster, succumbing to the error of looking for pathology where there was only everyday unhappiness. ‚ÄúYou have a chemical imbalance in your brain‚Äîyou are lacking serotonin,‚Äù I would earnestly explain to patients in whom I detected symptoms of depression, prescription pad at the ready. Little did I know that I was uttering scientific nonfacts. Yes, the medication was helping me, at least in the short term. And yes, I have witnessed other cases where psychiatric drugs were life-enhancing and even lifesaving. But we have to avoid the fallacy of inferring from medication‚Äôs (in some cases) observable benefits that the proven origin of mental illness rests in the biochemistry of the brain, let alone that physiological disturbances are genetically caused.&#13; That a medication has a certain positive effect reveals nothing about the genesis of a symptom. If aspirin eases a headache, can the headache be explained by an inherited brain deficiency of acetylsalicylic acid, the pill‚Äôs active ingredient? If a shot of bourbon relaxes you, is your tense nervous system suffering from a DNA-dictated whiskey shortage? There are fifty or more neurotransmitters in the brain whose complex interactions we are only now beginning to explore, not to mention the almost infinite possibilities inherent in the lifelong intersection of experience with the biology of body and brain. Once again, the physiology of the brain is a manifestation and a product of life in motion and in context.&#13; Further, as Bruce Perry writes, ‚ÄúThe brain is a historical organ. It stores our personal narrative.‚Äù Since it does so in the form of its chemistry and its neural networks, it is no wonder that difficult experiences may result in disturbed neurobiology. Even when brain scans show certain abnormalities‚Äîas they do, for example, in many traumatized people‚Äîthese do not prove that the ‚Äúdisorder‚Äù has a neurochemical source. A recently published thirty-year study followed people from early life to age twenty-nine. Poor quality of care in infancy was, nearly three decades later, associated with a higher volume of the emotionally key brain structure, the hippocampus, as well as with an elevated risk for ‚Äúborderline personality‚Äù features and suicidality. In other words, the brain‚Äôs genetics did not ‚Äúcause‚Äù either the ‚Äúillness‚Äù or the neurophysiological differences: all were the result of life experience.[9]&#13; The British author Johann Hari has explored addictions and depression from both the personal and journalistic points of view. In his bestselling work Lost Connections, he relates his own experience of devastatingly low moods, followed by his initial elation at the depression diagnosis that, at last, ‚Äúexplained‚Äù his disturbing mind states. ‚ÄúThis will sound odd,‚Äù he writes, ‚Äúbut what I experienced at that moment was a happy jolt‚Äîlike unexpectedly finding a pile of money down the back of your sofa. There is a term for feeling like this! It is a medical condition, like diabetes or irritable bowel syndrome.‚Äù&#13; Like mine, Hari‚Äôs first experience of medications was positive. ‚ÄúIt was only years later,‚Äù he relates in Lost Connections, ‚Äúthat somebody pointed out to me all the questions the doctor didn‚Äôt ask that day. Like: Is there any reason you might feel distressed? What‚Äôs been happening in your life? Is there anything hurting you we might want to change?‚Äù The answers would have been yeses all around: Hari was carrying both past trauma and present stress that he took to be part of his ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù Over time, he came to recognize that the narrow medical model that had helped him manage his symptoms was also leaving him far short of healing. He is not entirely jaded about the biological approach, he told me, but he also noted with sorrow that ‚Äúit has crowded out the much more common-sense insights that people have about why they become distressed and how to resolve their distress. Really‚Äîhow do I put it‚Äîit‚Äôs given us an inaccurate map of our own pain.‚Äù&#13; It is known beyond controversy that the greater the degree of childhood adversity, the higher the risk of mental disturbances, including psychosis. One study found that people who had suffered five types of maltreatment in childhood were multiple times more likely to be diagnosed with psychosis than those who had not experienced such traumatic events.[10] A major review in 2018 in the Schizophrenia Bulletin concluded that the severity of childhood traumas was correlated with the intensity of delusions and hallucinations.[11] Richard Bentall, a clinical psychologist, academic, and Fellow of the British Academy, summed up the science a few years ago: ‚ÄúThe evidence of a link between childhood misfortune and future psychiatric disorder is about as strong statistically as the link between smoking and lung cancer,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúThere is also now strong evidence that these kinds of experiences affect brain structure, explaining many of the abnormal neuro-imaging findings that have been reported for psychiatric patients.‚Äù[12] This mirrored a Harvard study that concluded, ‚ÄúThese brain changes may be best understood as adaptive responses to facilitate survival and reproduction in the face of adversity. Their relationship to psychopathology is complex.‚Äù[13]&#13; There is something scientists reviewing research papers will not say, although it is manifestly evident to many clinicians working with mental distress: overt maltreatment is not necessary to exert negative impacts on the neurobiology of the brain or the functioning of the mind. Neurobiology is a continuum, as are ‚Äúmental illness‚Äù and health. Emotional injury during development can have physiological consequences, even without abuse or neglect. As Bruce Perry explains, adverse childhood experiences‚Äîof the big-ticket kind that merit the official ACE designation‚Äîare of consequence, but ‚Äúnot as determinative as your history in relationships . . . The most powerful predictor of your functioning in the present is your current relational connectedness and then the second most powerful component that we see is your history of connectedness.‚Äù&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be so sensitive,‚Äù people are often told. In other words, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be so yourself.‚Äù Genetic vulnerabilities do not code for illness, but they may confer sensitivity for a person being more impacted by life‚Äôs vicissitudes than someone else with a hardier predisposition‚Äîa far from trivial effect. Sensitive people feel more, feel deeply, and are more easily overwhelmed by stress, not just subjectively but physiologically. Both monkeys and humans, for example, can inherit genes involved in the production of certain brain chemicals such as serotonin that can make them more susceptible to negative experiences‚Äîor, on the other hand, more amenable to the effect of positive ones. (And, of course, sensitivity, too, is a continuum.)&#13; ‚ÄúGenes affect how sensitive one is to environment, and environment affects how relevant one‚Äôs genetic differences may be,‚Äù the leading geneticist R. C. Lewontin has said. ‚ÄúWhen an environment changes, all bets are off.‚Äù[14] Some people will feel more pain and will therefore have greater need to escape into the adaptations that mental illness, or addiction, represent. They will have more need to tune out, to dissociate, to split into parts, to develop fantasies to account for realities they are unable to endure. But that‚Äôs a far cry from saying that they have a heritable neurobiological disease. These are the children that Tom Boyce, a professor of pediatrics and psychiatry at the University of California, San Francisco, describes as orchids, ‚Äúexquisitely sensitive to their environment, making them especially vulnerable under conditions of adversity but unusually vital, creative, and successful within supportive, nurturing environments.‚Äù[15] The same ‚Äúsensitivity‚Äù genes that in a stressed environment can help potentiate mental suffering may, under positive circumstances, help promote stronger mental resilience and therefore happiness.[16] Sensitive people have the potential to be more aware, insightful, inventive, artistic, and empathic, if their sensitivity is not crushed by maltreatment or disdain. The most sensitive of our kind have made some of the most lasting cultural contributions; many of these have also suffered the most intense pains during their lives. Sensitivity can be the quintessential combo package: gift and curse, all in one.&#13; Many of the people I‚Äôve met with mental illness exhibit this quality, sometimes to astounding degrees. I‚Äôll never forget a conversation I had as a medical student with a psychotic young man about my age. Tall and disheveled, he gazed at me with piercing eyes as I lobbed him some questions related to a meaningless research project for which I was getting paid. Inwardly, I was awed by his insights into life, society, the secrets of existence, into human beings. I was wishing as I listened that I could have access to such awareness. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not true what you‚Äôre thinking,‚Äù he abruptly interjected. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not true I‚Äôm more intelligent than you are.‚Äù&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; Despite the genetic hoopla in the popular media and all the lavishly funded DNA-hunting in the scientific world, no one has ever identified any gene that causes mental illness, nor any group of genes that code for specific mental health conditions or are required for the presence of mental disorder. Professor Jehannine Austin, an academic and researcher, leads a genetic counseling clinic for mental health in Vancouver.[*] ‚ÄúEverybody has some genes that predispose to mental illness,‚Äù she told me, but these are ‚Äúa very, very long way away from causing anything . . . Literally what separates those of us who do suffer from those of us that don‚Äôt is what happens to us during our lives.‚Äù&#13; I believe there is more than meets the eye when it comes to the persistent appetite for genetic causes. There are the factors I‚Äôve already covered: reticence to face trauma on the one hand, and the neglect of developmental science on the other. There is also the standard-issue preference for a simple and quickly understood explanation, along with our tendency to look for one-to-one causations for almost everything. Life in its wondrous complexity does not conform to such easy reductions.&#13; Other psychological and sociological dynamics add to the adhesive appeal of genetic theories. The first shouldn‚Äôt come as any news: we all hate feeling culpable. Whether as individuals for our own actions, as parents for our children‚Äôs hurts, or as a society for our many failings, we have our ten-foot poles at the ready when accountability comes to call. Genetics‚Äîthat neutral, impersonal handmaiden of Nature‚Äîseems to absolve us of responsibility and of its ominous shadow, guilt. If genes truly rule our fate like capricious, microscopic gods, then we are off the hook.&#13; The genetic argument is used to justify social inequalities and injustices that are otherwise hard to defend. Much like junk sciences of the past‚Äîphrenology, eugenics, and so on‚Äîit serves a deeply conservative function: if phenomena like addiction or mental distress are determined mostly by biological heredity, we are spared from having to look at how our social environment supports, or does not support, the parents of young children, and at how social attitudes, prejudices, and policies burden, stress, and exclude certain segments of the population, thereby increasing their propensity for suffering. The writer Louis Menand said it well in a New Yorker article: ‚Äú‚ÄòIt‚Äôs all in the genes‚Äô: an explanation for the way things are that does not threaten the way things are. Why should someone feel unhappy or engage in antisocial behavior when that person is living in the freest and most prosperous nation on earth? It can‚Äôt be the system! There must be a flaw in the wiring somewhere.‚Äù[17]&#13; There is a stark paradox in all this. To the extent that we cling to genetic fundamentalism to avoid the discomforts of personal responsibility or societal reckoning, we radically‚Äîand unnecessarily‚Äîdisempower ourselves from dealing either actively or proactively with suffering of all kinds. It is entirely possible to embrace responsibility without taking on the useless baggage of guilt or blame. Even more regrettably, we miss the excellent news that if our mental health is not dictated by our genes, then we are not their victims. On the contrary, there is much we can do, each and all.&#13; &#13;

 &#13; Chapter 18&#13; The Mind Can Do Some Amazing Things: From Madness to Meaning&#13; &#13; Perhaps the line between sanity and madness must be drawn relative to the place where we stand. Perhaps it is possible to be, at the same time, mad when viewed from one perspective and sane when viewed from another.&#13; ‚ÄîRichard Bentall, Madness Explained: Psychosis and Human Nature&#13; &#13; If we are not to see mental distress solely as illness, then what is it? The view I have come to favor is of a piece with how I approach many other conditions under the ‚Äúillness‚Äù umbrella: rather than seeing it as an intruder from the outside, consider what it might be expressing about the life in which it arises. This framework is, if anything, all the more intuitive when it comes to afflictions that take up unwanted residence in the mind, in a person‚Äôs emotional world, in the personality.&#13; Let‚Äôs begin with something rather simple, now on the rise: depression, a state I know intimately. The word‚Äôs literal meaning is quite telling. To depress something means to push it down, as one might a beach ball in a swimming pool. I like that analogy especially because one can easily feel how much concerted force it takes to keep the ball submerged, and the way it ‚Äúwants‚Äù to find a way back up to the surface. Keeping it down takes a toll.&#13; What is pushed down when a person is depressed is easily identified by its absence: emotion, the continual flow of feelings that remind us we‚Äôre alive. Unlike the wrangler of the beach ball, a depressed person doesn‚Äôt choose this submersion of life energy‚Äîit imposes itself, turning a once-vibrant emotional landscape into arid desert. The only ‚Äúfeeling‚Äù that remains, typically, is more sensation than emotion, a thrumming, indistinct pain that threatens to consume everything, and sometimes does. If we label this depression of feeling a disease, we risk not recognizing its original adaptive function: to distance oneself from emotions that are unbearable at a time in life when to experience them is to court greater calamity. Recall what I called the tragic tension between authenticity and attachment. When experiencing and expressing what we feel threatens our closest relationships, we suppress. More accurately, we don‚Äôt: our mind does that automatically and unconsciously on our behalf.&#13; The origin story of my own depression is easy to trace. It is documented in the trove of family photographs, from infancy onward, in which there is hardly ever even a hint of a smile on my face. Gazing at you from these pictures is a child who, at best, is serious beyond his age, when not morose. Under the conditions of war and genocide, I absorbed the feelings of my grief-stricken and terrorized mother; in my earliest photos I see my little self almost mirroring them. ‚ÄúThe child can . . . feel the tension, rigidity and pain in the body of the mother or of anyone else he is with,‚Äù writes the psychological thinker and spiritual teacher A. H. Almaas. ‚ÄúIf the mother is suffering, the baby suffers too. The pain never gets discharged.‚Äù[1] I could not have endured such emotional torment if I had felt it fully‚Äîno infant could. Nor was there room for my own sorrow and rage at the separation from my mother at less than one year of age.&#13; As I have noted before, such extreme circumstances as beset my infancy and childhood are not required to induce a splitting from self. The riskiest emotions, and thus the most frequently exiled, are acute grief and healthy anger, two feelings that often get tarred as ‚Äúnegative.‚Äù[*] Of course, a child may also have cause to banish her joy, enthusiasm, or pride if these arouse disapproval, envy, or just blank incomprehension on the part of parents too stressed, distracted, or depressed themselves. Either way, repressing the rejected emotion is the surest way of escaping overwhelming levels of vulnerability, of avoiding a too-painful rift between oneself and the ambient world. There is a catch, however: we cannot select which emotions to force below consciousness, nor willfully reverse the mechanism even after it has outlived its usefulness. ‚ÄúEverybody knows there is no finesse or accuracy of suppression,‚Äù wrote the American novelist Saul Bellow in The Adventures of Augie March; ‚Äúif you hold down one thing, you hold down the adjoining.‚Äù Thus the repression of emotion, while adaptive in one circumstance, can become a state of chronic disconnect, a withdrawal from life. It becomes programmed into the brain, embedded in the personality.&#13; The neuroscientist Jaak Panksepp, who studied the biology of the brain‚Äôs emotional systems as thoroughly as anyone, had scathing words for the physiological disease model. ‚ÄúPopular depictions of depression as a ‚Äòchemical imbalance‚Äô are trivial . . . [All] problems in living, including death, are accompanied by ‚Äòchemical imbalances,‚Äô‚Äù he pointed out. He, too, saw depression as an adaptation of the brain to the loss of connection, as a physiological ‚Äúshutdown mechanism‚Äù to terminate distress, ‚Äúwhich, if sustained, would be dangerous for infant mammals.‚Äù[2] In other words, far from expressing inherited pathology, depression appears as a coping mechanism to alleviate grief and rage and to inhibit behaviors that would invite danger. It is not that neurotransmitters are not involved in depression‚Äîonly that their abnormalities reflect experiences, rather than being the primary cause of them. Brain disturbances manifest the stresses of existence during formative periods and, once established, become a source of further stress. Hence follow, Dr. Panksepp concluded, ‚Äúthe diverse symptoms and variants of depressive illness.‚Äù&#13; It has been transformative for me to realize that my own mental health issues carry genuine meanings that arose from my life within my family of origin in a particular historical context. I have found the same to be true universally, no matter where I look, whose mental ‚Äúillness‚Äù I consider, or indeed how extreme the condition happens to be. If anything, the more flagrant ones are easier to decode. When examined, the manifestations of all the various mental health diagnoses have meaning, from depression through what is called schizophrenia to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, from troubled eating patterns to self-cutting.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; ‚ÄúBefore becoming a clinical psychologist, I was considered by some to be a seriously mentally ill patient,‚Äù New York therapist No√´l Hunter recalls in her book Trauma and Madness in Mental Health Services. Prior to seeking help in early adulthood, she had been living with intense distress and a sense of ‚Äúbeing controlled.‚Äù ‚ÄúI was just all over the place,‚Äù she told me, ‚Äúand was very scared of being hospitalized. I saw about six or seven different psychologists, social workers, psychiatrists at that time, and accrued about eight different diagnoses throughout all of that as well.‚Äù She was placed on five medications, which she was assured she would have to rely on for the rest of her life. ‚ÄúI feared having my own children one day lest I pass on my genetic faults,‚Äù she writes. ‚ÄúThe fact that there was unfathomable abuse throughout my entire family, that coldness and greed superseded nurturance and love, and that emotional neglect was balanced only by an intrusive lack of boundaries all seemed irrelevant.‚Äù[3] The meaning, once sought, was crystal clear and had nothing of the insane in it: Hunter‚Äôs ‚Äúparanoia‚Äù was a faithful, unerring emotional imprint of childhood. Without getting into the details, there had been a time in her life when, young and helpless, she was controlled by powerful, hostile figures in ways she found hurtful and scary, ways that violated her neural expectations and distorted her sense of reality.&#13; The mind is a meaning-making machine. It will generate stories that ‚Äúmake sense‚Äù of the emotions that, at a vulnerable time, it could not contain and perhaps still cannot. Yet in the individual‚Äôs unspoken history, the emotions were real, and therefore still are. They can surface in a number of different ways, such as Dr. Hunter‚Äôs belief in being ‚Äúcontrolled‚Äù as a young adult. To other minds, such narratives appear as madness itself. ‚ÄúIt comes out as somewhat fantastical, so we say, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs totally non-understandable,‚Äô‚Äù Hunter remarked. In my experience, the story underneath diagnostic labels like hers is always perfectly coherent if one seeks the truth in the emotional texture and the biographical record rather than in the content of the paranoid fantasy. Coming to see this coherence and integrate it into her sense of self has enabled Hunter to understand and regulate herself differently. Today she is long off her ‚Äúlifetime‚Äù pharmacological agents. I have witnessed many such examples and know of many more.&#13; Forty-year-old Leslie, a recently certified therapist who is now pursuing an MA in psychology, made over a dozen suicide attempts or serious suicidal gestures from age seventeen to her mid-thirties. Leslie was plagued by chronic insomnia, cried uncontrollably, and could not maintain relationships. Her medical chart was a smorgasbord of DSM nomenclature: chronic depression, borderline personality disorder, dysthymia, panic disorder, ADHD, and, briefly, bipolar disorder. She had also been diagnosed with chronic cystitis and fibromyalgia. At one point she was on five different psychiatric medications, including two antidepressants, an antipsychotic, and a benzodiazepine tranquilizer, and was prescribed a third antidepressant intended to soothe her physical pain, along with an anti-inflammatory.&#13; Leslie‚Äôs healing journey‚Äîshe, too, is no longer on any medications‚Äîhas centered on finding the meaning in her multifaceted sufferings. Her crushing belief in her unworthiness revealed itself to be a self-protective strategy gone awry. Odd as it may sound, it was the best worst option. A suffering child, as Leslie was‚Äîagain, the details matter less than the contours‚Äîhas two possible options when it comes to processing her experience. She can conclude either that the people she relies on for love are incompetent, malicious, or otherwise ill-suited to the task, and she is all alone in this scary world; or that she herself is to blame for, well, everything. As painful as the latter explanation is, it is far preferable to the other one, which paints a life-threatening picture for a young being with zero power or recourse. The first option is not an option at all. Better to believe ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my fault; I‚Äôm bad,‚Äù which lets you believe there‚Äôs the chance that ‚Äúif I work hard and be good, I will be lovable.‚Äù Thus, even the debilitating belief in one‚Äôs unworthiness, nearly universal among people with mental health diagnoses and addictions, begins as a coping mechanism, a topic we will revisit in chapter 30.&#13; What of Leslie‚Äôs chronic state of panic? Her supposed ‚Äúbrain disorder‚Äù was, in fact, the expression of a mind alarmed by early hurt. It is adaptive for the brain of a child in her situation to be in a state of hyperalert fear, even when no immediate danger is present. These adaptations to adversity, once habitual, cannot discern between major and minor threats‚Äîor no threat at all. The capacity to recognize safety or threat will evolve in a healthy way under conditions of safety but be disrupted by prolonged early insecurity. Possible outcomes include feeling besieged when there is no threat, or conversely, remaining oblivious to danger when it is present.[4]&#13; Leslie has even learned to have compassion for her self-hurting compulsions. ‚ÄúThey were actually trying to protect me from the deep pain that I was in or trying not to feel,‚Äù she said. These included hitting herself with a leather belt, as her mother had done when Leslie was a child. When I asked her what that did for her, she answered: ‚ÄúIt would kind of calm me down a bit. I would be less dysregulated.‚Äù Surprising but true: the very mental patterns and behaviors that seem to throw our lives into such chaos originate as an attempt, a temporarily and partially effective one, to regulate our nervous systems, to bring our bodies and minds to equilibrium.&#13; The incidence of self-cutting is rising, particularly among young people. If we resist the default to ‚Äúmental illness‚Äù as an explanation for such acts, we might ask instead: Why do people harm themselves? As in Leslie‚Äôs case, these behaviors play the role, paradoxically enough, of self-soothing. They bring short-term relief. That more and more people are resorting to self-harm is a marker of the growing prevalence of stress and trauma. The comedian Darrell Hammond told me that cutting himself afforded him ‚Äúa crisis that‚Äôs more manageable than the terror inside you, the one that‚Äôs going on in your head . . . You look at a cutter‚Äôs arms; those aren‚Äôt suicide cuts. Those aren‚Äôt death cuts. Those are either ‚ÄòI want someone to know I‚Äôm in distress,‚Äô or ‚ÄòWhen I start patching this arm up, running and finding the Band-Aid, and cleaning myself up, I have a crisis, but it‚Äôs manageable, and the one in my head was not.‚Äô‚Äù The Canadian Indigenous writer Helen Knott depicts the same process with scorching eloquence: ‚ÄúThose brief moments of the sharp blade dragging across skin provided me with a relief from the hate that I felt for myself. It was as if the moment the skin opened up, it became a vent that poured out all of my fucked-up whirling emotions . . . I didn‚Äôt want to die at that time‚Äîthat‚Äôs not what cutting was about. I was doing it so I could put up with living.‚Äù[5]&#13; Thus, many actions and beliefs that look like pure insanity from one perspective make sense from another‚Äîand always made sense at the start. It is our task, if healing is the goal, to make sense of them newly, now, with the benefit of adult discernment and compassion.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; We can derive this same lesson from the tragic life of the great comic actor Robin Williams. On August 10, 2014, the night before he died by suicide, Williams attended a soiree in his posh San Francisco Bay Area neighborhood. The others at the party would have seen the effervescent, people-loving persona for which he was so well known. Underneath that mask, he was in despair.&#13; Williams was in the throes of Lewy body disease, a neurodegenerative brain disorder characterized by Parkinsonian symptoms and advancing dementia. Unlike depression or anxiety, this ailment does have distinct physiological markings, even if they can be identified only in an autopsy. ‚ÄúRobin was losing his mind and he was aware of it,‚Äù his wife revealed after his death. ‚ÄúHe kept saying, ‚ÄòI just want to reboot my brain.‚Äô‚Äù The thought of suicide, however, was not new to him; in a 2010 interview he recriminated himself for ‚Äúnot having the balls to do it.‚Äù&#13; In addition to the madcap, on-the-fly brilliance of his work as a comic, he had a sweetness and vulnerability that touched many hearts, a love that poured out into the world but that he could never extend to himself.&#13; The founts of the comedian‚Äôs anguish can be located in his childhood. The author Anne Lamott grew up near Williams in Illinois. In a much-circulated Facebook post, she wrote that, as children, ‚Äúwe were in the same boat‚Äîscared, shy, with terrible self-esteem and grandiosity.‚Äù His lifelong dilemma, she said, would remain ‚Äúhow to stay one step ahead of the abyss.‚Äù&#13; In the same post, Lamott alluded to heredity as a likely cause of her friend‚Äôs sufferings. Yet I hear in Williams‚Äôs own words more than enough information to account for his mental-emotional woes without resorting to genetic superstitions. ‚ÄúMy only companions, my only friends as a child were my imagination,‚Äù he once said, an admission of profound loneliness.[6] He initially honed his extraordinary capacity to generate strange and hilarious imaginary characters as a way of breaking his isolation, in a family with an emotionally distant mother and a father he recalled as ‚Äúfrightening.‚Äù As many sensitive kids are in the peer culture, he was bullied at school. He found some freedom in fantasy, as his characters ‚Äúcould say and do things I was afraid to do myself.‚Äù His comic skills had the original function of gaining him some closeness with his mother. ‚ÄúYou get this weird desire to connect with her through comedy and entertainment,‚Äù he told the podcaster Marc Maron in 2010. His wording was unkind to himself: there is nothing weird about a child seeking attachment with his parent. What is abnormal is that any child should have to do so. Hence the same coping mechanisms that potentiated his greatest gifts ended up becoming the bars of his prison‚Äîthe double bind of the hypersensitive child, once again. Underneath his brilliantly turbulent comic persona, he learned to suppress his real feelings. He was past master at that, until his death.&#13; Cocaine, he once implied, gave him respite from his supercharged energy, just as a hyperactive child may be given the stimulant Ritalin to settle him. He had the addict‚Äôs lifelong discomfort with the self, the need to flee from his consciousness of himself: ‚Äúsleepwalking with activity,‚Äù he called it. In an episode of the hit 1970s television series Mork &amp; Mindy, he played both the outer space arrival Mork and his real self. ‚ÄúYou know, if you learned to say no, you‚Äôd probably have a lot more time to yourself,‚Äù Mindy tells the comedian. ‚ÄúMaybe that‚Äôs the last thing I want,‚Äù Robin replies, with an ineffably sad expression on his face.&#13; It wasn‚Äôt for lack of self-awareness that the abyss got the better of Williams in the end. Long before he developed a degenerative disorder, he suffered from what he called ‚Äúplease-love-me syndrome,‚Äù a self-diagnosis far more penetrating than anything a DSM-toting psychiatrist could come up with. I find myself wishing someone had guided him to connect the dots, to see that ‚Äúsyndrome‚Äù as the emotional endoskeleton of his manic-depressive swings, addictions, and suicidality, and very likely his terminal brain condition as well.[*][7] From there, he could have traced the links back even further to the scared, isolated child he once had been. He might have found the meaning that could have saved him.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; What, then, of conditions widely believed to be brain diseases, largely rooted in genetics, such as the group of diverse behaviors and thought patterns called schizophrenia, marked often by psychoses, delusions, and hallucinations? The science is clear and, again, belies popular prejudice. No ‚Äúschizophrenia gene‚Äù has ever been found‚Äîor, more accurately, claims of its discovery have had to be serially retracted. Broad surveys have found that at most only about 4 percent of the risk can be attributed to a wide variety of genes‚Äînone of them specific to this condition, as they are also seen in cases of ADHD or autism.[8] Again, what is being transmitted, if anything, is sensitivity and not disease. Even the nomenclature should give us pause: the Greek origin of ‚Äúschizophrenia‚Äù means ‚Äúsplit mind.‚Äù The question follows naturally: Why would a mind need to split itself?&#13; Self-fragmentation is one of the defenses evoked when the experience of how things are cannot be endured. Only those who know real life to be an insufferable bane are impelled to check out from it. No fixed genetic destiny here, but a survival need composed of constitutional vulnerability and overwhelming life experience. One way for an organism to escape that agony, whatever its source, is to disconnect whenever the distressing emotions are triggered. In the face of trauma, splitting from the present is a form of instantaneous self-defense.[9] From that perspective, it is a miraculous dynamic allowing vulnerable creatures to survive the unendurable.&#13; In psychoses there occurs a prime feature of severe mental illness, disintegration. In such extreme states, with normally related mental processes utterly separated, the person may be completely detached from the here and now. Such is the case in schizophrenia, but absenting oneself from reality can show up in a range of forms from mild to severe, depending on the degree of hurt and the genetic sensitivity of the individual.&#13; A milder flight from reality is dissociation. Helen Knott, subjected to sexual exploitation when very young, describes it well: ‚ÄúMy feelings left my body. My spirit sat outside of me like an unacknowledged apparition. I didn‚Äôt know whose life I was living, whose body I inhabited. This wasn‚Äôt my story, my life, my reality . . . I was scared that if I tried to lean into my feelings, I would fall off the emotional edge and I didn‚Äôt know what I would do to myself.‚Äù[10] What we call a disorder is revealed to be an ingenious means for an assaulted psyche to absent itself from agony.&#13; Such is also the recollection of the former National Hockey League star Theoren Fleury, who was sexually assaulted by his coach as a teenager and went on to become an advocate for childhood victims of sexual abuse. ‚ÄúThe first few times he got at me weren‚Äôt so bad because I was gone. I would open my eyes and he would be standing over me, cleaning himself up. I knew something had happened, but I was not sure what. The mind can do some amazing things. Even years later in therapy, when telling the counselor about it, I would check out‚Äîleave my body. She‚Äôd have to literally shake me to bring me back.‚Äù[11] Horrific though the inciting circumstances were, I hear in Fleury‚Äôs use of the word ‚Äúamazing‚Äù an appreciation for the parts of himself that mobilized way back when to protect him from pain‚Äîan attitude I heartily recommend to anyone making similar discoveries.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; A chronic, reflexive tuning out is one of the hallmarks of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD),[*] now being diagnosed worldwide with increasing and alarming frequency. This is not dissociation-level ‚Äúout of body‚Äù‚Äìness, but it does disconnect one from oneself, from one‚Äôs activities, and from other people in ways that disrupt functioning and are, as I personally attest, often highly frustrating. ADHD‚Äôs features include poor attention span, distractibility and low boredom threshold, poor impulse control, and (mostly in males) difficulty being still. Millions of children are receiving stimulants as a result, and hundreds of thousands are even being treated with antipsychotic medications‚Äînot for psychosis, but simply to calm them, to make them more pliable. This amounts to a vast and uncontrolled social experiment in the chemical control of children‚Äôs behavior, since we don‚Äôt know the long-term effects of such drugs on the developing brain. What we do know from adult research should give us pause. It has been understood since at least 2010 that prolonged use of antipsychotics is associated with shrinkage of brain volume in adult subjects.[12] In children we are already witnessing some short-term systemic harm. Here in Vancouver, British Columbia Children‚Äôs Hospital has had to establish a special clinic just to deal with the metabolic consequences of such drugs, which include obesity, diabetes, and threats to cardiovascular health.&#13; ADHD is sometimes said to be the ‚Äúmost heritable‚Äù mental illness, which in my view is a bit like calling quartz the most chewable crystal. Some experts estimate‚ÄîI should say misestimate‚Äîthe heritability of ADHD traits to be in the range of 30 to 50 percent.[13] The genetic thesis never made sense to me, even though two of my children and I myself have been diagnosed with this ‚Äúbrain disease.‚Äù Tuning out is dissociation‚Äôs less extreme cousin, part of the same family of escapist adaptations. It is invoked by the organism when the circumstances are stressful and there is no other recourse for relief, when one can neither change the situation nor escape it. Such was the imperative in my own infancy.
