As Joan Didion remarked about the latter, for journalists ‚Äúwhat ‚Äòfairness‚Äô has often come to mean is a scrupulous passivity, an agreement to cover the story not as it is occurring but as it is presented, which is to say as it is manufactured.‚Äù[4] That leaves it up to each of us, as individuals and as groups, to seek out and support alternative sources of knowledge, to expose ourselves to uncertainty, to enter into the points of view of others, whether we agree with them or not, to listen to people doing hard activist work on the ground, to stay alert to the many tendrils the myth of normal extends to keep itself normalized. This would represent a new kind of citizenship, one arising from the needs and demands of the moment.&#13; A Trauma-Conscious Society&#13; It‚Äôs hard to think of any collective domain where greater trauma awareness and insight into the nature of healing would not make a positive difference. I want to focus in these last pages on a few key ones.&#13; The implications of a society being trauma-literate could be immense. Since trauma is the core dynamic undergirding so much ill health, we need to develop the eyes and ears to spot it to begin with. Some see encouraging signs: my colleague Bessel van der Kolk goes so far as to assert that ‚Äúwe are on the verge of becoming a trauma-conscious society.‚Äù[5] I do not share that optimism in the short term, because that consciousness is still far from penetrating the decisive institutions of our culture. But I agree there is a recent sea change in the public‚Äôs recognition of trauma‚Äôs prevalence and significance in our lives. Many people, both lay and professional, are hungry to understand it. We see that in the long-term bestseller status of Bessel‚Äôs foundational text and the gratifyingly impressive success of books like Dr. Bruce Perry‚Äôs What Happened to You?, co-written with Oprah Winfrey. As too, if I may use it as an example, in the viral success of a film documenting my work, The Wisdom of Trauma, which was eye-opening in this regard even for me‚Äîit was seen by four million people in over 220 countries within two weeks of its release in June 2021.[*]&#13; Trauma Awareness: Medicine&#13; A trauma-informed medical system, for starters, could help heal and prevent suffering on a scale and in ways inspiring to envision. Such a system would revamp how health care is delivered, aligning itself with the latest scientific findings. Published almost every week in leading science journals, these findings have yet to make much of a dent in mainstream medical thinking. In this book we have cited many already, and more appear regularly.[6]&#13; At present there remains powerful resistance to trauma awareness on the part of the medical profession‚Äîalbeit a resistance more subliminal than deliberate, more passive than active. In the dozens of interviews I conducted with medical colleagues for this book, including recent graduates, virtually none of them recalled being taught about the mind-body unity or the profusely documented relationship between, for example, trauma and mental illness or addictions‚Äîlet alone the links between adversity and physical disease. We doctors pride ourselves on what we call evidence-based practice while ignoring vast swaths of evidence that call into question central tenets of our dogma.&#13; Then there is the highly stressed and often emotionally wounding or numbing impact of medical education, an experience reported by so many of my medical interviewees. ‚ÄúI was totally traumatized in my first year of medical school,‚Äù a well-known colleague told me. ‚ÄúIt was teaching by terror, as in intimidating us to learn when we‚Äôre already highly motivated to learn.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an abusive system; it‚Äôs a traumatic system,‚Äù my friend the Colorado psychiatrist Will Van Derveer said. ‚ÄúResidents [doctors] are killing themselves.‚Äù His words brought to mind the study I mentioned in chapter 4 showing that the telomeres of physicians in training frayed more rapidly than those of other young people their age. Aside from the health dangers to these health care professionals themselves, trauma unawareness impedes them from recognizing the imprints of painful life experiences in others. Thus, unwittingly, they perpetuate a system that ignores and even compounds the real problem. A harried existence and the time constraints imposed, especially by fee-for-service models, inhibit physicians from delving into their patients‚Äô life histories, even when they are inclined to do so. Residents gave me heartbreaking accounts of listening to patients‚Äô personal stories with the effect of almost immediate symptom relief, only to be denigrated by their specialist mentors. Medical students find themselves criticized for not working fast enough. I interviewed Oregon physician Pamela Wible, whose own painful trajectory has led her to work in preventing suicide among doctors. ‚ÄúNever in my wildest dreams,‚Äù Wible confessed, ‚Äúdid I think that after jumping through all the hoops of medical education I‚Äôd end up funneled into seven-minute office visits, and be treated as a factory worker, and be expected to treat my patients as widgets.‚Äù A trauma-informed medical system would have care for the emotional health of its students and practitioners.&#13; And yet, there are positive developments. Some medical schools are introducing elements of empathy training, and in Canada, there have been initiatives to acquaint medical students with Indigenous history and traditions. Pediatrician Nadine Burke Harris, a well-known trauma awareness advocate and now the surgeon general of California, is introducing screening for adverse childhood experiences into public health programs in her state. In an interview held before her appointment to the post, she expressed an optimism that mirrors Bessel van der Kolk‚Äôs. ‚ÄúBelieve it or not,‚Äù she told me, ‚Äúit‚Äôs going better than I‚Äôd hoped. I think we are looking at incremental milestones that need to happen over thirty or forty years‚Äô time, but a lot of groundwork is taking place.‚Äù For his part, Will Van Derveer has initiated a popular trauma-focused training for fellow psychiatrists, subscribed to by colleagues from around the world. And Pam Wible has pioneered a community-based approach that respects the bodymind unity and helps empower people to be active agents in their health care. ‚ÄúMedicine,‚Äù she told me, ‚Äúis a calling and it‚Äôs a soul‚Äôs purpose.‚Äù She has now created a way to follow that call.&#13; Trauma Awareness: The Law&#13; Can we next imagine a trauma-informed legal apparatus, one that could earn its title of ‚Äúcorrectional system‚Äù? Such a system would have to dedicate itself to actually correcting things in a humane way, a far cry from what we have now. In North America, and in many parts of the world, the current model should more accurately be called a ‚Äútrauma-punishing-and-inducing system.‚Äù Despite the documented fact that a large number of prison inmates committed their crimes out of dynamics originating in severe childhood suffering, legal training leaves the average lawyer or judge even more woefully trauma-ignorant than their medical counterparts. True to its other customary name, morally speaking, ours is a criminal justice system.&#13; A trauma-informed legal system would not justify or excuse harmful behavior. Rather, it would replace nakedly punitive measures with programs designed to rehabilitate people and not to further traumatize them. ‚ÄúAll us criminals start out as normal people just like anyone else, but then things happen in life that tear us apart, that make us into something capable of hurting other people,‚Äù writes the academic and former inmate Jesse Thistle. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all any of the darkness really is. Love gone bad. We‚Äôre just broken-hearted people hurt by life.‚Äù[7] ‚ÄúUnlike in some other countries, here prison is not designed to rehabilitate you,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs designed to mess you up so that you‚Äôll continue with high rates of recidivism, that‚Äôs what I think.‚Äù&#13; Dr. Nneka Jones Tapia, a psychologist, is a former prison guard and currently the managing director of Chicago Beyond and Justice Initiatives. As a Black woman, she knows institutionalized racial trauma well. She spoke to me of resilience and the creation of a trauma-informed justice system. ‚ÄúWe tend to reduce people to their behaviors: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre a murderer, you‚Äôre a robber, you‚Äôre a thief.‚Äô But we are not our worst behavior. I have had the blessing to see that everyone who is incarcerated has strengths and they have the capability of loving, if only we gave them the opportunity. It‚Äôs not just people that need the healing. It‚Äôs the system that has to be indicted and transformed.‚Äù&#13; Trauma Awareness: Education&#13; Because trauma affects kids‚Äô ability to learn, a trauma-informed educational system would train teachers to be well versed in the science of development. Education in such a system would encourage an atmosphere where emotional intelligence is valued as highly as intellectual achievement. We would no longer evaluate kids based on performance goals that still mostly reflect and bestow social and racial advantage, but would provide settings where all were encouraged to thrive. ‚ÄúSchool programs could be designed to support healthy social and emotional development,‚Äù writes teacher and school psychologist Maggie Kline. ‚ÄúWhen students feel safe, the regions of the brain for language, thinking, and reasoning are enhanced.‚Äù[8] Teacher training would recognize signs and signals of children‚Äôs ‚Äúacting out‚Äù as pleas for help or markers of emotional pain, rather than viewing them as bad behaviors to be suppressed or as cause for punishment or exclusion.&#13; Beyond schooling, the potential implications of my friend Raffi Cavoukian‚Äôs vision of an entire society that honors the irreducible needs of children (see chapter 9) are both vast and simple. I leave it to you, the reader, to imagine what our world would look like if we placed young people‚Äôs well-being in the forefront. What would it mean for parenting and for support for parenting, for childcare and education, for the economy, for what products we sell and buy, for what foods we sell and prepare, for the climate, for the culture? What if our intention, as parents, as educators, as a society, was to raise children in touch with their feelings, authentically empowered to express them, to think independently and be prepared to act on behalf of their principles?&#13; A healthy society would also strive to close the largely artificial generation gap that makes it difficult for parents to relate to their kids and vice versa. As discussed in an earlier section on peer orientation (chapter 13), the natural human arrangement has a strong communal dimension, and the adult community is meant to work together to hold space for the development of the young. That does not mean lording it over our kids, nor dictating every aspect of their lives, only that we reclaim responsibility for creating and maintaining the container for their growth. And we must also remember that parents need each other, and that we all need the presence of life-tested elders; in a world that‚Äôs committed to health, child-rearing and intergenerational transmission of values and culture wouldn‚Äôt be an isolating task.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; In the last decades, in many countries around the world, people‚Äîadults and children in the millions‚Äîhave mobilized to force into the political conversation critical issues such as environmental justice, Indigenous rights, women‚Äôs rights, gender justice, racial equity, and police reform. One such person is Greta Thunberg, the teenage climate activist, who, describing her autism as her ‚Äúsuperpower,‚Äù has contributed greatly to her generation‚Äôs awareness of climate change. ‚ÄúMany ignorant people still see it as an ‚Äòillness,‚Äô or something negative,‚Äù she said on Twitter. ‚ÄúWhen the haters go after your looks and differences, it means they have nowhere left to go. And then you know you are winning.‚Äù Her own example illustrates the healing power of meaningful engagement. Prior to her climate campaign, she divulged, she had ‚Äúno energy, no friends and I didn‚Äôt speak to anyone. I just sat alone at home, with an eating disorder.‚Äù[9]&#13; Inspired by figures like Thunberg and countless others whose names we may never know, we can revisit our list of the four A‚Äôs I laid out in chapter 26 that promote healing‚Äîauthenticity, agency, anger, and acceptance‚Äîand add two more that are required for the pursuit of broad transformational change: activism and advocacy. The last two are socially meaningful ways of synthesizing the previous four, with some added ingredients‚Äîsolidarity, collective thinking, and connection‚Äîto help counter capitalism‚Äôs atomizing effects.&#13; Part of advocacy is to use whatever privilege we may have to amplify the voices of those to whom society denies a voice; part of activism is organizing groups of people to demand necessary change. Both express a healthy, necessary ‚Äúno,‚Äù often accompanied by a resounding ‚Äúyes‚Äù‚Äîfor example, to a concrete policy goal like Medicare for All in the United States or long-overdue justice for First Nations people in Canada. These two bonus A‚Äôs are not, and cannot be, individual pursuits. I visited Zuccotti Park in New York City, in September 2011, the site of the Occupy Wall Street protests against inequality. Flawed and evanescent as that movement proved to be, I was struck by the enthusiasm, solidarity, and sheer energy of the crowd as they found a collective outlet for forwarding their vision of a just society. Often blocked from being expressed, that latent energy is within us all.&#13; The photographer Nan Goldin, whose addiction to opiates we touched on in chapter 15, has waged more than a private struggle for recovery: she has engaged in both personal and collective activism against Purdue Pharma, the corporation that helped generate the opioid overdose crisis that has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives. Purdue reaped vast profits from its drug OxyContin, which it marketed as a less addictive opioid painkiller, suppressing evidence to the contrary. Goldin‚Äôs friends in AA had advised against her going public, saying it would destroy her sobriety. ‚ÄúIt turned out to be the best choice I ever made,‚Äù she told me.&#13; Her particular crusade has been directed against the Sacklers, the family that controls Purdue. Goldin‚Äôs fame as an artist gave her a platform to raise her banner, especially since the Sacklers have cultivated a reputation as art benefactors. ‚ÄúI knew their names from going to museums,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúand I always thought of them as benevolent art philanthropists with great taste.‚Äù Another salutary disillusionment, I thought. ‚ÄúAnd then I found out,‚Äù Goldin continued, ‚Äúabout their involvement with the opiate crisis, their profiting off the suffering of hundreds of thousands of people, their complete callousness and inhumanity.‚Äù Fueled by outrage at what she discovered, Goldin induced some of the world‚Äôs most prestigious museums, including the Met in New York, to stop accepting money from the Sacklers and to eliminate their self-laundering logo from their buildings. The Sackler Institute of Graduate Biomedical Sciences at NYU‚Äôs medical school has also dropped the family name.&#13; I asked Goldin why she saw her decision to engage in public activism as the best choice she ever made. Her answer speaks to the health rewards of the two added A‚Äôs of activism and advocacy. ‚ÄúYou need something bigger than yourself,‚Äù she replied without hesitation. ‚ÄúFor me what‚Äôs bigger than myself is other people suffering. And that‚Äôs a situation I can help rectify. The politics of this moment are bigger than any individual, the way the world is right now. Trying to find a way to impact that, that‚Äôs my power, that‚Äôs what I fight about. It helps keep me sober.‚Äù As Goldin found, standing up to a toxic system can help us find a place to stand within ourselves.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; It is never redundant to remind ourselves that the Chinese phrase for ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù is a compound of symbols for ‚Äúdanger‚Äù and ‚Äúopportunity.‚Äù&#13; We have seen how people with debilitating and even life-threatening pathology can learn from their illnesses and transform their lives. If the same principle were applied on a societal scale, the climate crisis would be an opportunity to examine the dominant perceptions and practices of a culture on a path of self-destruction. The COVID-19 experience, which, ironically enough, has done much to unmask many unflattering facts about our ways of life, is a powerful reminder of the interconnections between all life-forms; of our true nature rooted in our relationship to one another; of the inequities of a system in which the most socially vulnerable are left most open to attack by a deadly virus; of how the slogan ‚ÄúWe are all in this together‚Äù is a sad fiction when it comes to the economic ravages and windfalls of the public health catastrophe that has marked this decade for all time.&#13; And speaking of crises, there could be no more damning indictment of a system than that its young people, stalked as they are by anxieties about human-made climate change, distrust adults and governments en masse.[10] The inimitable Greta Thunberg put it with devastating simplicity at a youth summit in Milan held in September 2021: ‚ÄúBuild Back Better. Blah, blah, blah. Green economy. Blah blah blah. Net zero by 2050. Blah, blah, blah. This is all we hear from our so-called leaders. Words that sound great but so far have not led to action. Our hopes and ambitions drown in their empty promises.‚Äù[11] Unfettered greed, inauthenticity, and disconnection have driven us to such a dark place that it falls to young people to wake us up to what this toxic culture has perpetrated and ignored for so long.&#13; &#13; ‚Äî&#13; Prior to his trial for war crimes, the master engineer of Nazi genocide SS Lieutenant Colonel Adolf Eichmann was certified as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù by several psychiatrists‚Äî‚Äúmore normal, at any rate than I am,‚Äù one of them was said to have exclaimed according to Hannah Arendt‚Äôs classic account.[12] ‚ÄúAnother,‚Äù Arendt reported, ‚Äúhad found that Eichmann‚Äôs whole psychological outlook, including his relationship with his wife and children, his mother and father, his brothers and sisters and friends, was ‚Äònot only normal but most desirable.‚Äô‚Äù&#13; This is what the American psychiatrist Robert J. Lifton has termed ‚Äúmalignant normality.‚Äù Many of the greatest crimes have been and continue to be perpetrated by people in leadership positions who are deemed to be the epitome of normal in their respective societies, whether it‚Äôs the production of toxic and climate-altering chemicals or, say, the imposition of policies that lead to mass starvation in countries far away. Hundreds of thousands of Iraqi children died of malnutrition in the 1990s because of U.S. sanctions.[13] America‚Äôs then‚ÄìU.N. ambassador Madeleine Albright declared that ‚Äúthe price is worth it,‚Äù in an interview seen by millions. As we now know, and as anyone could have known then, there was no credible justification for such heartless cruelty. Albright subsequently became the first woman secretary of state and remains highly respected, especially in liberal circles.[*] One is reminded of Victor Hugo‚Äôs withering phrase for such figures: ‚Äúthe barbarians of civilization.‚Äù&#13; As it turns out, it is often individuals who defy conventional normality who are the healthy ones. The psychologist Abraham Maslow made the investigation of self-actualization‚Äîthe attainment of authentic satisfaction not based on external valuations‚Äîhis life‚Äôs work. ‚ÄúA study of people healthy enough to be self-actualized,‚Äù he wrote in a widely read paper, ‚Äúrevealed that they were not ‚Äòwell-adjusted‚Äô (in the na√Øve sense of approval of and identification with the culture).‚Äù These healthy people, suggested Maslow, had a complex relationship with their ‚Äúmuch less healthy culture.‚Äù Neither conformists nor automatically reflexive rebels, such men and women expressed their unconventionality in ways that kept them true to their inner values, without hostility but not without fight, when that was called for. ‚ÄúAn inner feeling of detachment from the culture was not necessarily conscious but was displayed by almost all . . . They very frequently seemed to be able to stand off from it as if they did not quite belong to it.‚Äù[14]&#13; As we saw earlier, the antidote to the hypnotizing influence of normality is authenticity: finding meaning in one‚Äôs inner experience, unobscured by societally promulgated fictions‚Äîprime among them what Daniel Siegel calls ‚Äúthe lie of the separate solo self.‚Äù That falsehood is the ultimate abnormality. From where I stand, a life devoted to seeing through such a traumatizing nontruth, dwelling and creating outside its bounds, is a life lived well.&#13; It all starts with waking up: waking up to what is real and authentic in and around us and what isn‚Äôt; waking up to who we are and who we‚Äôre not; waking up to what our bodies are expressing and what our minds are suppressing; waking up to our wounds and our gifts; waking up to what we have believed and what we actually value; waking up to what we will no longer tolerate and what we can now accept; waking up to the myths that bind us and the interconnections that define us; waking up to the past as it has been, the present as it is, and the future as it may yet be; waking up, most especially, to the gap between what our essence calls for and what ‚Äúnormal‚Äù has demanded of us.&#13; We are blessed with a momentous opportunity. Shedding toxic myths of disconnection from ourselves, from one another, and from the planet, we can bring what is normal and what is natural, bit by bit, closer together. It is a task for the ages: one that can redeem the past, inspire the present, and point to a brighter, healthier future.&#13; It is our most daunting challenge and greatest possibility.&#13; &#13;
